abstract: Powder, agglomerates, and tablets of the microporous zirconium(IV) terephthalate metal–organic framework UiO-66 were evaluated for the selective adsorption and separation of xylene isomers in the liquid phase using -heptane as the eluent. Pulse experiments, performed at 313 K in the presence of -heptane, revealed the -xylene preference of this material, which was further confirmed by binary and multicomponent breakthrough experiments in the presence of - and -xylene, resulting in selectivities at 313 K of 1.8 and 2.4 with regards to -xylene and -xylene, respectively. Additionally, because -xylene is the less retained isomer, UiO-66 presents a selectivity pattern that is reverse of that of the xylenes' molecular dimension with respect to shape selectivity. The shaping of the material as tablets did not significantly change its selectivity toward the -xylene isomer or toward -xylene, which was the less retained isomer, despite a loss in capacity. Finally, the selectivity behavior of UiO-66 in the liquid -heptane phase makes it a suitable material for -xylene separation in the extract (heavy product) or -xylene separation in the raffinate (light product) by simulated moving bed technology.

10.1021/la3004118 Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionPacked Bed Preparation and ActivationResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesIntroductionMany applications of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged recently as a highly interesting topic in drug delivery, selective molecular sieving, and heterogeneous catalysis.(1-9)Their very high porosity and versatile composition and topology, together with accessible metal sites or adaptive porosities, make MOFs very interesting candidates for separation.Xylenes constitute a family of C8 aromatics that are generally produced as a mixture containing the three xylene isomers (o-, m-, and p-xylene) and ethylbenzene. The xylene isomers differ one from another by the relative positions of the methyl groups in the benzene ring.(10, 11) Over time, the demand for xylenes has increased because they are used as raw materials in several industries. o-Xylene is used to produce phthalic anhydride, which is employed as a plasticizer. m-Xylene is used to produce isophthalic acid, which is gaining broader acceptance in poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) resin blends. p-Xylene, the isomer with the broadest commercial importance, is used as a raw material in the manufacture of PET, which in turn is used to produce fibbers, resins, films, and blown beverage bottles.(10-12) In this way, their separation is an important process in the production of pure xylenes. Adsorbents with a high selectivity toward o-xylene or p-xylene, the two isomers with the broadest commercial interest, are desired. Such materials would increase the efficiency of the existing processes. A high p-xylene-selective adsorbent would contribute to the decrease in the simulated moving bed unit size or to the decrease in the eluent consumption. A high o-xylene-selective porous material would be the core of an adsorption-based process to replace the energy-demanding xylene splitter and o-xylene distillation column in an existing state-of-the-art aromatics plant.In the literature, different MOFs were presented as good materials to be used in xylene isomer separation, such as Zn(BDC),(13) MOF-5, MOF monoclinic,(14) MIL-47,(15, 16) MIL-53(17-20) (MIL stands for materials from Institut Lavoisier), UiO-66(21)(UiO stands for the University of Oslo), and, more recently, MIL-125(Ti)(22, 23) and MIL-125(Ti)_NH2.(23)Some MOFs, such as UiO-66,(21) have shown interesting features in the selective adsorption of xylene isomers in the gas phase. Some of us have recently reported(21) that the adsorption of the bulkier o-xylene is favored over that of the other isomers in zirconium terephthalate UiO-66. This selective adsorption is opposite of the adsorption process usually applied in industry, which depends on the matching of the pore size and shape of the adsorbates and the adsorbent micropores.(24)UiO-66, built from zirconium oxoclusters Zr6O4(OH)4 and 1,4-benzene-dicarboxylate (BDC or terephthalate),(25, 26) exhibits a cubic 3D structure with two types of microporous octahedral (∼11 Å) and tetrahedral cages (∼8 Å), which are accessible through microporous windows of around 5–7 Å,(21, 26) as presented in Figure 1. Thus, according to Bárcia et al.,(21) the retention of alkanes and aromatic molecules in UiO-66 could be attributed to the rotational freedom of the adsorbed molecules inside the smaller cavity.Figure 1. View of the UiO-66 tetrahedral and octahedral cages. The 3D optimized structure was generated with ChemBio3D Ultra from CambridgeSoft. Zirconium, oxygen, carbon, and hydrogen atoms are in dark gray, red, light gray, and white, respectively.Thus, we propose here to evaluate the potential application of the powder or shaped (as agglomerates or tablets) UiO-66 solid for xylene separation in the liquid phase by using fixed bed experiments on both laboratory and pilot scales. First, pulse experiments were performed on the laboratory unit in order to evaluate the behavior of UiO-66 at low concentrations. Then, binary breakthrough experiments were conducted on the laboratory scale to determine the adsorption isotherm at 313 K, using n-heptane as an eluent. Multicomponent breakthrough experiments were then carried out to calculate the corresponding selectivities. Finally, multicomponent breakthrough experiments were performed on the pilot scale unit at 313 K and 9 bars.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionPacked Bed Preparation and ActivationResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesExperimental SectionChemicals and EquipmentA UiO-66 powder sample was synthesized by Institut Lavoisier (ILV) as previously reported from a solution of 32.2 g of ZrOCl2.8H2O, 16 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 500 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF), and 16 mL of HCl (37%) heated to 423 K under air for 24 h. (For more details, see the Supporting Information.) For the same purpose, the Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT) synthesized and supplied UiO-66 in the form of tablets. Shaping of UiO-66 powder into the form of cylindrical tablets (3 mm diameter × 5 mm length) was carried out using a rotary press tabletizer. Before the shaping work was done, pretableting of the powders with subsequent grinding and sieving was done with a laboratory press in order to fit the density to more than 0.25 g/mL. The pretableted UiO-66 granule was uniformly mixed with a small amount of a graphite powder (1%) through ball milling. Then, the solid mixture was fed into the rotary press tabletizer to form a shaped body consisting of 99 wt % UiO-66 and 1 wt % graphite. Finally, the cylindrical tablets were formed by the combined pressing action of two punches and a die with holes of 3 mm diameter. After being shaped, the resulting surface area of the pelletized sample is 885 m2/g (SBET). The apparent bulk density of the tablets is 0.8 g/cm3.Gas-chromatography (GC)-grade p-xylene, o-xylene, and m-xylene (purity >99.0%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as adsorbates. On the basis of the literature(19)n-heptane (99.5% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a solvent.UiO-66 tablets were morphologically characterized at Centro de Materiais da Universidade do Porto (CEMUP) by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) operated at 15 kV (FEI Quanta 400 FEG ESEM). SEM was performed using a magnification of 60 to 1500× to observe UiO-66 tablets in detail.Helium pycnometry and mercury porosimetry analyses were performed at Laboratório de Caracterização e Certificação de Materiais Granulares (IPN - LabGran). Pore size distribution measurements were performed using mercury porosimetry (Micromeritics AutoPore IV 9500). The N2 physisorption isotherm of the pelletized sample was collected at 77 K after evacuation at 423 K for 12 h using a volumetric sorption analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar 3000).The xylene isomers' separation using UiO-66 as an adsorbent was evaluated through breakthrough experiments using two different units: a laboratory scale unit and a pilot scale unit. The laboratory scale unit corresponds to a Shimadzu HPLC apparatus (Kyoto, Japan) comprising one model LC-20AD UFLC pump, an FRC-10A fraction collector, an oven model CTO-20A equipped with a stainless steel column, and an SPD-M20A IVDD diode array detector with a CBM-20A control system. The pilot scale unit comprises two HPLC pumps, a back-pressure regulator, a fraction collector, and an oven where a stainless steel column is placed. For detailed information, see Supporting Information.The laboratory scale unit has the advantage of allowing good performance of the fixed bed experiments using a smaller amount of sample. In this way, it is suitable for the powder and pelletized material; however, the tablets had to be crushed and sieved in order to be used in the column. Fixed-bed experiments using UiO-66 tablets as provided by KRICT were conducted on the pilot scale unit. Another advantage of this unit is the possibility to test the adsorbent at higher temperature and pressure, closer to real industrial conditions. The material preparation and activation procedure will be described in subsequent subsections.Prior to any experiment, a blank experiment was conducted in both setups to determine the dead volume. The experimental results were corrected accordingly.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionPacked Bed Preparation and ActivationResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesPacked Bed Preparation and ActivationPreparation of Packed BedsColumn AA stainless steel column was packed with 0.45 g of UiO-66 powder (i.e., powder UiO-66, Figure 2a) as provided by ILV. The tablets were crushed and sieved; the recovered fraction ranged from 300 to 500 μm (i.e., UiO-66 agglomerates, Figure 2b) and was used to pack the column. All experiments were performed at 313 K using a flow rate of 0.20 or 0.25 cm3/min, for powder (column A) or the agglomerate (column B) material, respectively. Initially, the column was fed with eluent until thermal equilibrium was reached. At this point, the column feed was switched to the xylene solutions and samples were collected. Reverse breakthrough experiments were performed by switching the column feed from the xylene solution to n-heptane. The experimental protocol was repeated using the powder and the pelletized material under the same conditions.Similar experiments were performed on the pilot scale unit for further comparison using column C. Breakthrough and reverse breakthrough experiments were carried out at 313 K at a flow rate of 5.48 cm3/min. After the column was filled with n-heptane and thermal equilibrium was reached, the column feed was switched from the eluent to the xylene solution. SEM images shown in Figure 3 reveal that UiO-66 tablets are agglomerates of around 5 × 3 mm composed of polydistributed and faceted crystals. This observation is consistent with the technique used for shaping, a rotary press tabletizer, which usually leads to the crystal breaking.Figure 3. The agglomerates possess about 65% of the powder capacity, whereas that from tablets as provided by KRICT reaches about 58%. This value is in accordance with the reduction of the BET surface area of the UiO-66 tablets reported in Table 1. According to these results, one can conclude that the shaped material suffers from a loss of capacity. This might be due first to problems issuing from the scale-up of UiO-66 synthesis itself because the powder used for comparison was provided by ILV and was produced on a smaller scale. The powder produced in a larger quantity might be poisoned by some amorphous denser phase that would contribute to the loss of capacity. Other explanations for the decrease in the capacity might arise either from the pelletizing process due to compression or from the effect of the binder addition (though in this case it is only 1% graphite). Normally, the pelletizing process is considered to be the main reason for the loss of capacity from shaped materials.(28) In this case, we believe that this is due to the destruction of the crystalline phase by pressure during the pelletizing process. Moreover, UiO-66 tablets as provided by KRICT exhibit some degree of mass-transfer limitation, which is in accordance with the lower accessibility of the pores for the xylene isomers. This can influence the behavior of the material in multicomponent separation experiments. Although the shaped material shows an important decrease in capacity, loadings of the UiO-66 tablets provided by KRICT are higher than for the state-of-the-art faujasite-type zeolites: 1.75 mol/kg for KY-type zeolites(29) and 0.925 mol/kg for BaFAU.(12) Considering the novelty of the large scale of shaped UiO-66, this solid has a high potential for xylene isomer separation because by improving the shaping of the powder one might access a higher performance than for the actual state-of-the-art adsorbents.Multicomponent Breakthrough ExperimentsA ternary breakthrough experiment was also performed using column B (run 35) in the laboratory scale unit in order to determine the material selectivity. This experiment was performed following the procedure described previously. In the present case, breakthrough experiments were performed using an equimolar mixture of xylene isomers, and then eq 2 was simplified.(3)The values obtained for the selectivity of o-xylene over m-xylene and p-xylene are 1.1 and 1.2, respectively. This indicates that there is a low selectivity between the species at high concentrations; however, the pulse experiments indicate higher selectivities in the low-concentration region. Therefore, the same experiment was conducted using a diluted concentration of xylene isomers to feed the column (run 36); the concentrations used are presented in Table 8. At low concentration, the separation between o-xylene and the other isomers occurs, as shown in Figure 8c,d, achieving selectivities of 1.8 and 2.4 for o-xylene over m-xylene and p-xylene, respectively.Table 8. Breakthrough and reverse breakthrough curves performed on the laboratory scale unit using UiO-66 agglomerates at 313 K and 0.25 cm3/min for mixtures of (a, b) 33.3 wt % p-xylene, o-xylene, and m-xylene (run 35) and (c, d) 3 wt % p-xylene, o-xylene, and m-xylene in n-heptane (run 36).The same experiments were repeated on the pilot scale unit (runs 37 and 38) in order to compare the agglomerates with the larger tablets. (See the feed concentrations presented in Table 8.) The results obtained on the pilot scale unit using UiO-66 tablets (runs 37 and 38) confirm once more the orthoselectivity of UiO-66 at low concentrations (Figure 9). The selectivities of o-xylene over m- and p-xylene are 1.7 and 2.3, respectively, which are in good agreement with the results obtained on the laboratory unit (1.8 and 2.4, respectively). As indicated previously, several MOFs have been tested for xylene separation;(14-16) the most well studied is MIL-53(Al),(17-20) which is also ortho selective like UiO-66. The literature(15, 17) reports selectivities at low concentration on the order of 2.7 and 3.5 for o-xylene over m- and p-xylene, respectively. However, at higher concentration the selectivity decreased to 2.1 for o-xylene over m- and p-xylene.(19, 20) By comparing these two materials, it is possible to realize that MIL-53(Al) hardly differentiates m-xylene from p-xylene, whereas UiO-66 differentiates these two isomers. A study was also published(13) on xylene isomer separation in the vapor phase using MOF-1; this material is ortho-selective, with selectivities of 1.88 and 1.12 for o-xylene over p- and m-xylene, respectively. Other materials are found in the literature for xylene separation, namely, MIL-47,(15) which has selectivity values of 2.0 and 1.4 for o-xylene over m- and p-xylene, respectively. Whereas the MIL-47 and MIL-53 topology consists of 1D channels, UiO-66 is a 3D structure with cages connected by narrower windows. Denayer and co-workers reported that the selectivity in MIL-47 is due to packing in the channels, viz., entropy differences.(30, 31) However, the selectivity in MIL-53 is due to differences in the adsorption enthalpy of the different isomers.(30) In UiO-66, according to Barcia et al.,(21) the selectivity is due to entropic effects in the small tetrahedral cages, similar to that of the MIL-47 material. More recently, several experiments using MIL-125(Ti)(22, 23) and MIL-125(Ti)_NH2(23) were reported, which revealed them to be para-selective adsorbents. Breakthrough experiments performed with a diluted ternary mixture led to selectivity values of 1.5 and 1.6 for p-xylene over m- and o-xylene, respectively, when MIL-125(Ti) was used,(22) although its amino form, MIL-125(Ti)_NH2, presented selectivity values of 3.0 and 2.2 for p-xylene over m- and o-xylene.(23) The most well studied zeolites for this separation, FAU type and MFI type, are also p-xylene-selective. The state-of-the-art adsorbent is an ion-exchanged FAU zeolite, which has been studied by several authors.(12, 29) The reported selectivities for KY at 293 K are αp-xylene/m-xylene = 5.25, αp-xylene/o-xylene = 4.63, αp-xylene/eb = 1.94, and αm-xylene/o-xylene = 1.(29) The use of MFI-type zeolites in the xylene mixture separation has been broadly studied by several authors;(32-35) however, its application is mainly focused on membrane separation technology,(34, 35) and its major drawback is that its selectivity depends on the temperature because of framework flexibility.Figure 9. Breakthrough and reverse breakthrough curves reported for the pilot scale unit using UiO-66 tablets at 313 K and 5.48 cm3/min for mixtures of (a, b) 33.3 wt % p-xylene, o-xylene, and m-xylene (run 37) and (c, d) 3 wt % p-xylene, o-xylene, and m-xylene in n-heptane (run 38).In general, one can conclude that despite a loss of capacity due to shaping, UiO-66(Zr) tablets and agglomerates present selectivities that are similar to those of the powder. Therefore, UiO-66 it is a suitable material for o-xylene (extract) or p-xylene (raffinate) production by simulated moving bed technology, providing an opportunity for process design engineering to play a role in determining the operation conditions accordingly to the desired product.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionPacked Bed Preparation and ActivationResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesConclusionsMicroporous zirconium terephthalate UiO-66, either as a powder or shaped as agglomerates and tablets, has shown an interesting o-xylene preference in the liquid phase, besides presenting an overall reverse shape selectivity for the xylene isomers. Pulse experiments have shown the ortho selectivity of UiO-66, even in the presence of ternary mixtures. The o-xylene preference of UiO-66 is retained even in the presence of the other xylene isomers, showing interesting selectivity values at 313 K in the presence of n-heptane (1.8 and 2.4 for o-xylene over m- and p-xylene, respectively). Binary component and multicomponent breakthrough experiments, performed at different concentrations, revealed a preference of UiO-66 for o-xylene in dilute systems, with p-xylene being the less highly retained isomer.Finally, powder and shaped UiO-66 tablets are both ortho-selective and preserve the reverse shape selectivity, despite a significant loss of capacity in the tablets as a consequence of the shaping process. UiO-66 therefore becomes a suitable material for o-xylene or p-xylene separation at low concentrations.
